etymology.description: 天(天) (tiān, "heaven; sky") + 啊(啊) (a, "a modal particle expressing surprise or exclamation")
etymology.interpretation: The phrase 天啊 (tiān a) expresses surprise, shock, or amazement. The character 天(天) (tiān, "heaven; sky") invokes a greater power or the heavens, while the particle 啊(啊) (a, "a modal particle") emphasizes the emotional reaction. Together, this expression is akin to saying 'oh my god' in English.

parts.english: a modal particle expressing surprise or exclamation

examples.chinese: 天啊(天啊)，这真是太不可思议了(這真是太不可思議了)。
examples.pinyin: tiān a, zhè zhēn shì tài bùkěsīyì le.
examples.english: Oh my god, this is really unbelievable.

examples.chinese: 天啊(天啊)，你竟然赢了(你竟然贏了)！
examples.pinyin: tiān a, nǐ jìngrán yíng le!
examples.english: Oh my god, you actually won!
